quote: The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.
author: Franklin D. Roosevelt
context: From his first inaugural address during the Great Depression

quote: I have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.
author: Martin Luther King Jr.
context: From the 'I Have a Dream' speech during the March on Washington

quote: That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind.
author: Neil Armstrong
context: While stepping onto the lunar surface during the Apollo 11 mission

quote: The greatest glory in living lies not in never falling, but in rising every time we fall.
author: Nelson Mandela
context: From his autobiography 'Long Walk to Freedom'

quote: Be the change that you wish to see in the world.
author: Mahatma Gandhi
context: Often attributed to Gandhi, though exact source is debated

quote: Imagination is more important than knowledge.
author: Albert Einstein
context: From an interview reflecting on the role of creativity in scientific discovery
source: Often attributed to a 1929 interview in The Saturday Evening Post

quote: In the middle of difficulty lies opportunity.
author: Albert Einstein
context: Attributed to Einstein in discussions about facing scientific and personal challenges

quote: Government of the people, by the people, for the people, shall not perish from the earth.
author: Abraham Lincoln
context: From the Gettysburg Address during the American Civil War

quote: Those who deny freedom to others deserve it not for themselves.
author: Abraham Lincoln
context: From a letter arguing against the expansion of slavery
source: Letter to H.L. Pierce and others, April 6, 1859

quote: Success is not final, failure is not fatal: it is the courage to continue that counts.
author: Winston Churchill
context: Widely attributed to Churchill, capturing his wartime leadership philosophy

quote: Never, never, never give up.
author: Winston Churchill
context: Paraphrase of his speech encouraging British resilience during World War II

quote: We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit.
author: Aristotle
context: Paraphrase inspired by Aristotle's ideas on virtue and habit in his ethical works

quote: It does not matter how slowly you go as long as you do not stop.
author: Confucius
context: Attributed to Confucius in later compilations of his teachings
source: Attributed saying from the Analects tradition

quote: Nothing in life is to be feared, it is only to be understood.
author: Marie Curie
context: Reflecting on scientific discovery and the unknown in an age of rapid advances
source: Attributed to Curie in biographies and collected sayings

quote: Learning never exhausts the mind.
author: Leonardo da Vinci
context: From his notebooks reflecting on curiosity and the pursuit of knowledge

quote: If I have seen further it is by standing on the shoulders of giants.
author: Isaac Newton
context: From a letter acknowledging the work of earlier scientists

quote: Genius is one percent inspiration and ninety-nine percent perspiration.
author: Thomas Edison
context: Comment on the relationship between hard work and invention

quote: No one can make you feel inferior without your consent.
author: Eleanor Roosevelt
context: From her reflections on personal dignity and human rights
source: Often attributed to her 1940 book 'This Is My Story'

quote: In a gentle way, you can shake the world.
author: Mahatma Gandhi
context: Reflecting his philosophy of nonviolent resistance against injustice
source: Attributed saying from speeches and writings

quote: It always seems impossible until it is done.
author: Nelson Mandela
context: Widely quoted reflection on the struggle against apartheid
source: Attributed saying from speeches in the early 1990s
